abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            despite unlikely sustainability, and modest institutional
            development impacts. Among the several lessons learned, the
            first one addresses the issue of projects, such as this one,
            which are forerunners in nature, particularly in a
            transition economy, embarked in developing a framework for
            fiscal decentralization. This entails municipal
            accountability, i.e., investment needs are based on
            municipal decision-making. Albeit, coordination, and
            consistency between the various aspects of the loan were not
            anticipated, as were not revenue problems in light of
            falling water demand. However, the Bank's linkages with
            other water projects helped provide a consistent approach,
            showing comparative tariff structures, and proved useful for
            monitoring purposes, and in taking further steps. Other
            lessons reinforce the need for meaningful, and timely
            project indicators to guide project management, which as the
            case of the water demand curve proves, despite falling
            demands, installation of water meters, and higher tariffs
            combined to impact on unit water consumption, in line with
            urban Western Europe. However, the difficult aspects in
            evaluating municipal public utility performance, needs to be
            reviewed by a nationally appointed public service utility
            regulator, experienced, and outlined under the Bank's
            Programmatic Structural Adjustment lending.
